data.title: open a custom file viewer window without opening the default one
data.body:
I want to implement an extension to display a graphical presentation for a binary file. I have had a look at markdown extension. But it displays the customized preview window with the default editor window side by side. So I want to know:
1. Is there a method to only open the preview window (customized) without opening the default editor window.
2. Can the default editor window be embedded in a customized window
It will be great if extension developers can freely compose their customized window with the internal VSCode views such as Editor, Tab, etc.

data.title: Open a terminal in vscode cause crash when folder 's path contain chinese character
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro 14383.187 

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open a folder which contain any chinese character in VSCode 
2.  Press `Ctrl+``
3. Terminal will exit with code 1

I don't know why, however, I think it may caused by encoding .....

data.title: Selecting horizontally scrolled text

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:152
- OS Version:10Ann

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Make a really long line of text with empty lines above and below
2. Disable word wrap
3. Scroll out horizontally near to the end of the line
4. Quickly attempt to select ~80 characters on that line using the mouse without being snapped back to either adjacent empty line

VSCode should detect when I select text and lock the scroll location so that it can only be scrolled when the cursor nears the edge. When it does reach the edge it should continue at the same scroll speed as before without snapping back. The partial scroll lock is released when the mouse button is released. Upon release no snapping should take place.

data.title: File name indentation is confusing when File Icon Theme is enabled
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.2 (66f37fd2a99eb9d628dd374d81d78835b410c39b, 2016-09-12T13:30:03.456Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Enable File Icon Theme
2. Browse files

When icons are enabled, file names are pushed right and make it look like directories are expanded:
![snip_20160916161817](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6611598/18603764/33b8d362-7c29-11e6-815c-38d19e113ab4.png)

I believe that the file icons should line up with the directory expansion arrow icon

An image with transparent parts should be obvious. Adding checkmarks as default background of images is common in a lot of other applications.

data.title: Conditional breakpoints sometimes stop working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set a conditional breakpoint in a Nodejs project
2. Use it for a while
3. Get frustrated because the breakpoint stopped working, spend a lot of time thinking it's your code.
4. Restart application, hope it fixes the breakpoint -- it doesn't
5. Go back to using archaic breakpoint without conditions, inspect variable, see condition is met, wonder why isn't this working. 
6. Restart Visual Studio Code, jump for joy as the conditional breakpoint works again!
7. Write ticket on this website and hope super cool Microsoft developer notices my plebeian ticket.
8. Microsoft developer fixes issue!
9. Profit.
   Further detail:
   I am using conditional breakpoints to stop execution of my software once a condition has been reached such as the following:

txBuff[17] == 24

The breakpoint works for a little while, and then stops working. Restarting Visual Studio Code appears to fix the problem temporarily.

data.title: AutoHotkey
data.body:
I've programmed AutoHotkey to rewire my "home" and "end" keys which works great, but with the latest Visual Studio Code it does not work.  Here are my AutoHotkey mappings:

```
PrintScreen::Home
Insert::End
RCtrl::PrintScreen
```

The above script worked correctly with prior versions of Visual Studio Code.  And to reiterate, those mappings still work correctly elsewhere (such as the Sublime editor or in notepad).
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise, 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code.  
2. Open any file with text in it.
3. Try using AutoHotkey shortcuts / hotkeys.

The AutoHotkey hotkeys will not work.

data.title: Crashes with multibytes characters and backspace key
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a blank file
2. Set the language mode to JSON (seems to works with other languages too)
3. Type "😄😄😄😄😄😄😄😄😄😄", with quotes
4. Place cursor before the last quote
5. Press the backspace key multiple times

Following dialog appears:

> [Window Title]
> Visual Studio Code
> [Main Instruction]
> The window has crashed
> [Content]
> We are sorry for the inconvenience! You can reopen the window to continue where you left off.
> [Reopen] [Close]

Debug console contains following error one or multiple times:

> D:\Applications\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\getmac\out\lib\getmac.js:1216[1] - Grammar is in an endless loop - Grammar pushed & popped a rule without advancing
> scanNext @ D:\Applications\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\getmac\out\lib\getmac.js:1216
> _tokenizeString @ D:\Applications\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\getmac\out\lib\getmac.js:1191
> Grammar.tokenizeLine @ D:\Applications\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\node_modules\getmac\out\lib\getmac.js:1028
> e.tokenize @ index.html?config={"_"%3A[]%2C"disable-extensions"%3Atrue%2C"disableExtensions"%3Atrue%2C"locale"%3…:119
> tokenize @ index.html?config={"_"%3A[]%2C"disable-extensions"%3Atrue%2C"disableExtensions"%3Atrue%2C"locale"%3…:119
> t._updateTokensUntilLine @ index.html?config={"_"%3A[]%2C"disable-extensions"%3Atrue%2C"disableExtensions"%3Atrue%2C"locale"%3…:56
> t._revalidateTokensNow @ index.html?config={"_"%3A[]%2C"disable-extensions"%3Atrue%2C"disableExtensions"%3Atrue%2C"locale"%3…:56
> (anonymous function) @ index.html?config={"_"%3A[]%2C"disable-extensions"%3Atrue%2C"disableExtensions"%3Atrue%2C"locale"%3…:56

data.title: Color appended to preview html not properly theme dependent
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

The styles appended to the preview html by vscode properly capture the background color of the current theme, but seem to be a constant rbg(204, 204, 204) for dark theme or rbg(108, 108, 108) for light theme for the color style option rather than using what the current theme has set.

The most obvious example is using the "Monokai" theme. The default text color (using file type of Plain Text) has the value rgb(248, 248, 242). However, vscode still appends the style rbg(204, 204, 204) to the html.

Is this intended? It would be nice if VSCode appended the proper color so that the preview html can look as much as part of VSCode as a text editor.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any preview html with a variety of themes

data.title: Declarative contribution of custom explorers (based on tree models)
data.body:
Allowing extensions to contribute a file explorer-like viewlet would enable some interesting features such as:
- Outline views that display symbols from the opened file
- Custom file explorers, for example a file explorer that tightly integrates with source control
- Database explorer
- More cool stuff pulled from people's imaginations

Related issues:
- Feature request: symbols tree view https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5605
- Feature Request: File Outline View for TypeScript https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10788
- Feature Request: SVN Support https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/206
- Add outline view. https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/issues/107
- add functionality to show the type hierarchy https://github.com/Dart-Code/Dart-Code/issues/133

data.title: How to avoid jumping to other places in Find All References?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

![jump](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/18595351/28859708-7bf9-11e6-9adb-a521ec81b2b1.gif)

When I'm doing Find All References I hope I can just stay in the window. Jumping to random places loses me all context I've been working with.

I think Single click -> Show reference in the inline window, Double Click -> Go to the reference in file would be a better approach.

It also wouldn't hurt to add some decoration to the symbol that you are jumping to, and let it fade out after jumping there.

data.title: Crash when debugging extension and you close the dev tools too quickly

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VSCode Version: `Version 1.6.0-insider (1.6.0-insider)` 50bb7aad57cbf1924e28472de52734be49645558
OS Version: `OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.6 (15G1004)`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start debugging an extension
2. After the new instance of code starts, click the restart button in the main code instance
3. When the new instance starts again its dev tools seems to open (for some reason) and if you click its close button too quickly both instances of code crash

It might take a couple of times to get it to happen, but I can reproduce it quite reliably.

Currently in status bar we can see only number of sync remote/local commits on "Synchronize changes" button.
Can you split git-sidebar and in bottom part output names of remote/local commits? You can make combobox to choose which unsync commits to show: local or remote.

thank you.

data.title: Add file icon in file editors section
Bind numpad_add and numpad_subtract as alternates for zoom commands
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0-insider
  ![vscodeversion](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5934628/18589550/1a05ef7a-7be0-11e6-9bdf-5b21f303947b.png)
- OS Version: Windows 10 Insider build 14915

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Using a keyboard that has a keypad (large laptop in my case), try zooming with ctrl and the keypad plus/minus. This works in Firefox and many other applications as an alternative to the -/= keys between 0 and backspace on a US keyboard.
2. I think this should be doable with custom keybindings ala https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/keybindings but I haven't quite managed to get that working. This might be a standard and useful enough binding for these keys that it would be worth making default though? Opinions?

edit: #983 is somewhat related

data.title: Feature fequest for applying CSS styles in console.log

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Feature Request**

Chrome and Firefox both support applying CSS styles to console output.  For example, you can do something like `console.log("%cThis text should be green", "color: green");` and in Chrome and Firefox you get "_This text should be green_" in green text.

In the VSC console log you get "_color: greenThis text should be green_" and the output is styled the same as any other console.log output.  VSC should apply CSS styles to console.log in the same way as Chrome and Firefox.
